Baghdad Thursday July 7
Received
August 18th 1921
1921
last sheet
missing
Dearest Father . I must begin my weekly letter today, otherwise
I shall have far too much to say all at once. On Monday morning
a decisive thing happened. Mr Philby , who had been sick of a fever
at Hillah came back on Sunday night + interviewed Sir Percy the
following morning. Sir Percy told him to hand over to Mr Thomson . It's
a real tragedy, his dismissal, but he has no one but himself to thank.
Sir Percy had given him a very long rope. He sent him down to Basrah to
meet Faisal in the hope that the two would come to terms. Mr. Philby
did nothing but insist on the merits of Ibn Sa'ud + on his own
conviction that a republic was what the 'Iraq wanted. He told the
Advisor at Hillah, Major Dickson , to carry on with a projected
tour, so that Major Dickson was not at Hillah when Faisal
passed through. Major Dickson has been here since + has made his peace
with Faisal.
It is difficult to tell what spirit of evil has taken
hold of Mr Philby but the net result is that he has been
thoroughly disloyal to his Chief + disobedient to the orders of
his Government. Sir Percy, who never hesitates in what he
thinks to be his duty, has cut the knot, in the only possible
way. I am nevertheless very very sorry. On Tuesday I went
to see them in order to tell them so + had a most painful
interview. She burst into tears, accused me of having been
the cause of her husband's dismissal + went out of the
room. I then reminded him of our long friendship + asked
him to believe that I had done all I could to persuade him
that no government servant can profit by running
counter to orders. He talked very wildly, indeed the utmost
tosh. He said "You've won this time but we shall still
meet at
Philippi Likely a reference to the Battle of Philippi, where in 42BC Mark Antony and Octavian fought and defeated Brutus and Cassius, the leaders of Julius Caesar's assassination. In Shakespear's Julius Caesar, Caesar's spirit appears to Brutus before battle, and tells him "I shall see thee at Philippi." It seems that Philby is unhappy with the decisions made here and is warning Bell that he plans to fight them.
." I assured him he was mistaken
as regards Philippi because I should make a point of
not being there, + as for winning, the policy of
H. M. G. His Majesty's Government
had won as it always would. After that it wasn't any
good continuing the conversation, so I went away. I don't
know what they are going to do. They talk of going to

Most of the towns - I think I told you - have sent deputations
to greet Faisal. With these I exchange visits. The Basrah
deputation isn't very good, because the leading people there
want to be separated from the rest of the 'Iraq as told
I told you in my last letter; nevertheless Mr Cornwallis +
I went to tea with them yesterday. And in the
evening we went to an immense dinner party
given by Fakhri Jamil to all the deputations. I
should think there were 100 people there. The big
courtyard was carpeted + furnished + we
dined at two long tables in the open air. The
dinner was very long but the party broke up
pretty soon afterwards. It's rather a complication
in all these festivities, that the temperature is
120° - at least that's what it goes up to by
day.
One by one all the leaders of the rebellion are
coming in to pay their respects. Yusuf Suwaidi
came on Tuesday + got a fine dressing down
first from me + then from Sir Percy. However he
took it in good part + went away saying that
he was delighted with Sir Percy! All the
shaikhs Honorific title meaning 'Elder', used for leaders of tribes and royal family members.
+
saiyids Honorary title in Islam
who fought against us are turning up
also. I need not say that Sir Percy's handling of
them is perfect. They all repeat that if he had
been here there would have been no rising, which
is perfectly true. This morning an opportunity presented
itself + in which I could both do the right thing + the

Kermanshah
for the summer. I wish them well, but I know he
will never make a success of anything. He is too obstinately
convinced that there is no point of view but his own
How he could embrace the cause of that rogue Talib
passes all belief but he had identified himself with him +
since his removal he has been spinning a bad cotton.
Faisal + Talib are like light + darkness, + only one who
is blind can fail to detect the difference!
Meantime on that same Monday morning I was having a
crucial interview. The leading Christian Christian here, 'Abdul Jabbar Pasha ,
came in with the Mutasarrif + Naji Suwaidi to urge that
once Faisal had come we couldn't afford to wait for
elections + must resort to a Referendum to place him on
the throne. Abdul Jabbar is a member of the Council . We were all fully aware of this, indeed
Faisal had talked of it when I saw him on Saturday,
but he added that the one thing he feared was a
coup d'état + we must continue to make the proceedings
as constitutional as we could. The only show of Arab
Govt Government
is the Naqib in Council, though they are merely
an apparition created by Sir Percy . Still the next
move must come through them. Accordingly Sir Percy
saw the Naqib + it has been arranged that the
council shall ask him how soon the elections can take
place since there is obviously urgent need to come to a
settlement. Sir Percy has ascertained that we can't
get the registration of electors through under 2 months,
which is longer than we can afford. He will therefore
reply in that sense to the Council, but add that the Council
approves we can resort to a
speedier process. It will then,
to put it quite baldly, be up to us to rig the Council
which no doubt we can. I would rather have had elections
but 2 months is too long to wait + I hope that in our

present extremely favourable position we can get the country to
accept anything we approve. The local press has already begun
to talk about a referendum, without any inspiration. I really do
believe - I hope without exaggeration - that I have it in the
hollow of my hand. I read the 4 local papers every
morning + if there's anything I think unsuitable, I intimate
the fact to the editors, either directly or indirectly + they
come to heel at once! Today I had to do it directly.
One enthusiast had published a violent attack on the
French in Syria . I sent for him + proved to his
satisfaction that we had better leave the Syrians to
take care of themselves - we don't want to embark on
international complications while we are setting up an
Arab state here. He had also announced in his paper
that he intended to publish, a book of biographies of
all the leaders in
last year's revolt The revolt against British rule that began in May 1920 with the onset of mass meetings and demonstrations in Baghdad, also referred to as the 1920 Arab Revolt. The revolt ended in October 1920.
. I convinced him
that that also would not be advisable but I think I
shall have to give him some solid compensation for
the financial loss which his grave rifaits will
cost him. You need not mention any of these particulars
- it's part of the game, but one isn't usually so much
behind the scenes.
What helps everything is that Faisal's personality goes
three quarters of the way. He has been roping in adherents,
they most of them come round to me to be patted on the
back, a task at which I'm getting to be an adept.
It's a little more delicate if they come when they are
trembling on the brink but I then bring in the overwhelming
argument that Sir Percy + Faisal are walking hand in
hand - it's really remarkable how completely satisfied
they are if they know that Sir Percy approves. He has
an extraordinary hold on the country.

2
thing that pleased me - a rare combination. There came in one
of the leaders of
the revolt The revolt against British rule that began in May 1920 with the onset of mass meetings and demonstrations in Baghdad, also referred to as the 1920 Arab Revolt. The revolt ended in October 1920.
, a horrid worthless man, who
had a bubble reputation last year which has now
burst + disappeared, + I was more icily rude to him
than I've ever been to anyone. He had evidently hoped to climb back
into some sort of esteem by being allowed to see Sir Percy ; I gave
him pretty clearly to understand that Sir Percy could not receive
him + he retired in disorder. It was a great satisfaction.
Friday July 8 . Last night the Naqib gave a dinner to Faisal
in his house opposite his own mosque. The English guests were
Sir Percy + his staff (i.e. Mr Garbett + me) + the
GOC in C
General Officer Commander in Chief
+
2 of his staff. All the rest were the ministers + notables of
Baghdad . Sir Percy took me. The streets were crowded with people
as we drove up; the Naqib's family received us at the door + we
climbed up two flights of stairs onto a roof overlooking the mosque,
a sort of side balcony. It was carpeted + lighted; the mosque
door opposite was hung with lamps + the minarets ringed with
them. The Naqib was sitting with the ministers; he got up +
tottered forward to meet Sir Percy, a touching + dignified figure. The
rest of the guests, some 100 I should think, sat below us on the open
gallery which runs round two sides of the courtyard on the first
storey of the house. A burning wind blew on us while we drank
coffee + talked till the clapping of hands in the street anounced
the arrival of Faisal. The Naqib got up + helped by his
personal physician, walked across the whole of the carpeted
space + reached the head of the stairs just as Faisal's white-
robed figure appeared. They embraced formally on both cheeks
+ walked back hand in hand to the end of the balcony where
we were all standing up. Faisal sat down between the Naqib +
Sir Percy + after a few minutes dinner was announced. Faisal
Sir Percy the
C in C Commander in Chief
+ I went down; then the Naqib with a
servant on each side of him to help him. The long dinner table
stood on the open gallery. Faisal sat in the place of honour
opposite the Naqib with the C. in C. on one side of him + I on
the other. Sir Percy was on the Naqib's right, opposite me + I
had on the other side Izzat Pasha , a Turk of Kirkuk whose
goes

after which we spent another hour discussing the formation of
Faisal's first Cabinet + his very excellent idea of creating a
sort of Privy Council of shaikhs + notables. On the way home
I called on Sasun Eff . + told him about the letter to the
Council + how it was intended to provoke a request for a
referendum. And now if I don't go to bed I really shan't
be able to begin again tomorrow morning. Sunday 10th We're
all right I think. Yesterday I had in 'Abdul Majid Shawi + told him
delicately what was expected of the Council, of which he's a
member. He agreed with enthusiasm as he would to anything
we suggest, the old trump, + went off to secure several other
members. Before he left came Izzat Pasha with a request
for an interview with Sir Percy which I got him at once. Sir
Percy said "Do you think he wants to ask me why we brought
that man?" I said if it was that, it was now Sir Percy's
turn to answer. But it wasn't. Izzat came in to me
after the interview + related the conversation. He had come
to till Sir Percy that he had seen Faisal + could bring in
to him the Kurdish chiefs any time Sir Percy wished. Also
that he intended to speak up for a referendum in the
Council. "
Khatun Honorific title given to Bell.
" said he ''I've seen Walis + Sultans +
Generals but I've never yet seen anyone like Sir Percy +
as long as he is guiding us I am satisfied." It's true that
Sir Percy may easily be considered better than the average
Wali but Izzat's conviction that he was better than
anyone was unmistakable. Isn't it an extraordinary
position for any man to hold? The whole country waits for his
word. What should we have done without him? the answer to that
question is however obvious - we couldn't have done anything at
all. It is Mr Philby who has made it an uphill game. Yesterday,
for instance, the Mutasarrif of Nasiriyah came up. He
had been urging his shaikhs + townsmen to send in petitions
for a republic. And why? because his Advisor (Major
Ditchburn , you remember) had told him that that was how

attitude towards Arab government is very doubtful. We put him into
the Council + he has perpetually told me in private that he thinks
nothing of it, nor of any Arab institutions which aren't carried on
our shoulders. I was very glad to be sitting by Faisal + to leave
the opportunity for a good talk but after two or three
courses (there were 15 or 17 altogether) I handed him over
to Sir Aylmer (Faisal talks a very little French, no English) + made conversation to Izzat who is
rather a friend of mine. In the middle he turned his cynical
old eyes on me + said: "Why did you bring that man?" It
was a moment for straight speaking. I said "Do you want
an answer? it's because he is the best Arab of his day.
Is that enough?" "Yes" said Izzat "that's enough." After
that we all talked across the table with the Naqib + Sir
Percy , which was easier. But I hear Izzat had a long
private conversation with Faisal this morning + Faisal thinks
he has got him. If he has, he has got Kirkuk .
Towards the end of dinner one of our best orators made
a short + excellent speech followed by a shorter +
better poem the gist of which was that the conjunction
of the Naqib + the
Amir Title given to rulers or military leaders.
assured the future of the 'Iraq.
Each couplet ended with a very charming phrase
about standing in the house of the Naqib + before the face
of the Amir. The Naqib sat doubled up, looking
centuries old + murmured from time to time "good
words." I believe he intended to say something himself
but Faisal is very impatient of sitting after dinner +
after masses of fruit had been handed round, he got
up + what the Naqib might have said has unfortunately
been lost forever - a great pity. But it was a wonderful
sight that dinner party. The robes + the uniforms + the
crowds of servants; all brought up in the Naqib's
household - the ordered dignity of it + the real solid

magnificence, + the tension of spirit which one felt all round one
as one felt the burning heat of the night. For after all to the
best of our ability we were making history.
But you may rely upon one thing - I'll never engage in
creating kings again; it's too great a strain.
Well then we went back to our high balcony + arranged
ourselves on the seats, Faisal by the Naqib, + I brought up
another old thing of almost equal sanctity to sit on
the other side of him + sat down by the second old thing
myself so as to help the conversation to flow. But we
didn't have very long of it. Faisal went away amidst
end
the clappings of the crowd + we all took our leave. || Sir Percy
+ I as we drove home, felt we had jumped another hedge,
but we agreed that we there in a very stiff country.
Again today the same sort of morning in the office - it's
a morning which lasts from 7 till 1.30! Faisal was
then interviewing Sir Percy even before I got there. Then came
the heads of the
Mosul Mosul deputation The leading people of Mosul who came forward in support of proclaiming Faisal as king.
to ask me to arrange
their journey back, + incidentally confided to me that
they didn't think we ought to wait for elections to proclaim
Faisal king, which was good hearing. Then shaikhs to
interview Sir Percy + me + ask if they ought to go +
pay their respects on Faisal. And more people + more +
finally my best editor to whom I dropped a hint that
he might freely write articles in favour of a referendum.
After lunch Sir Percy, Mr Garbett + I drafted the
crucial letter to the Council, + soon after 3 I came
home to wash + change (it isn't the coolest part of the
day) + got to Faisal's house at 4 o'clock, with all the
trial maps to give him a lesson in tribal geography. Mr
Cornwallis turned up too. There at last it was cool
for we sat in a big vaulted room, half underground +
for an hour we studied tribes + drank iced lemonade,

3
the country was going, + Major Ditchburn got it from Mr Philby .
For it isn't only Sir Percy , it's all the British officers who at
this moment can mould public opinion. The people in the
provinces who don't see Sir Percy take the word from their
local man. I don't think this immense desire to do what
we want will continue. Last year they were all out against
us, this year they are all with us - what will they
be next year? But what we've got now is a great asset
for we can use it to guide the country at this critical moment.
In the same way I can't believe that our honeymoon with
the extremist press will endure, but it's enough for
me that at present that we're having a sort of love feast.
When it ends we'll find some other expedient.
In the evening old 'Abdul Jabbar Pasha came to see me at my
house, delighted that the Council should have an opportunity
for recommending a referendum, which was his idea from the first.
I confess I went to bed satisfied.
The Shamiyah shaikhs are now sending up deputations
to Faisal . They were very timid about it - that was because
Major Dickson hadn't been at Hillah to receive him! A boy
whose father I know - a small shaikhling on the
Hindiyah - came in two days ago to find out how
the land lay. Very shamefacedly he confided to me that
they had had letters from one of Faisal's supporters bidding
them come to Baghdad - what ought they to do?
I told him the obvious thing was to come - everyone was
coming. Was the Hindiyah going to be the only part of
Mesopotamia which didn't send a deputation? So I
confidently expect that the Hindiyah tribes will roll up
this week. That's what it's all like. They won't take a
step till they've asked the advice of one of us whom they know.
I've still in the back of my mind got a doubt about the
Shi'ah An Islamic sect who believe that the descendants of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
'alims Refers to an educated scholar of Islamic law.
+
mujtahids Refers to a person accepted as an original authority in Islamic law.
, confound them. We can do very
very little with them. Faisal thinks he has got them + I hope he

is right. But there are more splits + jealousies among them
than he knows of, + I fear he may have got only a bit of them.
That however is on the knees of the gods - or the devils.
I've been riding with Mr Tod this morning + I'm going to
swim tonight, + now there are heaps of letters to write.
Goodbye dearest. I've got your letter of
June 9
with
very interesting enclosures including your correspondence
with the Bp of Winchester . Good letter of yours to him.
Your very affectionate daughter
Gertrude
Late June or July?

Sir Hugh Bell Bart C B
